title: PES - He peak further left and higher than H

content.description: The photoelectron spectra for <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtext>H</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> and <math alttext="H e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>He</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are represented above.
content.question: Which of the following statements best accounts for the fact that the peak on the <math alttext="H e" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtext>He</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> spectrum is farther to the left and higher than the peak on the <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> spectrum?

choices.label: <math alttext="H e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>He</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has an additional valence electron in a higher energy level than the valence electron in <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="H e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>He</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has a greater nuclear charge than <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and an additional electron in the same energy level.

<math alttext="H e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>He</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has a completely filled valence shell in which the electrons are a greater distance from the nucleus than the distance between the <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> nucleus and its electron.

It takes longer for the electrons in <math alttext="H e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>He</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to be removed due to the higher nuclear mass of <math alttext="H e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>He</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="H e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>He</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has a greater nuclear charge than <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and an additional electron in the same energy level.
